Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: A Machine Learning Framework for Comprehensive Dental Caries Detection
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will be the development of an artificial intelligence software solution that enables automated detection of dental cavities in digital X-rays. Routine misdiagnosis of dental cavities (tooth decay) is a global challenge; cavities alone account for over 5% of healthcare costs in developed countries, with dental care focused on repairing rather than preventing tooth decay. This project will develop an add-on solution for software already in use by 200,000 dentists nationally. The technology resulting from this project will allow non-expert assistants to automate the triaging, screening, and tracking of patients, increasing access to oral care for underserved communities nationally and throughout the world.<br/><br/>This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will demonstrate the feasibility of two key innovations: (1) a novel software framework using an innovative neural network algorithm for the detection of cavities in X-rays, and (2) the worldâ€™s largest database of dental radiographs annotated by specialists in oral radiology. The goals of R&D are to achieve high sensitivity and specificity in cavity detection and to ensure consistent high-quality annotations. Outcomes include: (1) achieving state-of-the-art performance in cavity detection, (2) outperforming domain experts in detecting all stages of cavities, and (3) enabling professionals and non-experts alike to interpret pathologies using a visual heatmap of prediction confidence. The proposed technology features an innovative neural network structure for learning visual representations of dental radiographs that jointly characterize the data while highlighting their most salient attributes. Using a new and original training procedure, the technology will maximize the benefit of existing unlabeled data. Technical challenges include scaling performance while maintaining a minimal false-negative rate, establishing interoperability under various calibration settings, and achieving the desired level of results on the types of machines used by customers with reasonable resource costs.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tooth decay (the carious lesion, or "caries") is the most prevalent noncommunicable disease in the world. Yet the routine misdiagnosis of caries, with its irreversible consequences remains an unmet and underappreciated challenge: one in three dentists routinely miss radiographic caries; dental-related emergency room visits due to preventable conditions cost three times as much as dental visits; and, children and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups are significantly more likely to experience caries.

The mission of Dentuit, Inc. is to answer the as-yet unmet challenge of routine failures to detect dental caries for accurate diagnosis. With this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF), Dentuit has been able to perform the artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) research and development required to innovate and collaborate on an emerging technology, while de-risking the proposed solution with the foundational science required for safely achieving exactly that aim. Partnering with the University of Maryland, Baltimore, in particular their School of Dentistry (UMSOD), Dentuit has sought and found a dental AI/ML commercialization pathway emphasizing a scientific evidence-based approach to product development from the outset.

The result of this NSF STTR effort is Dentifai, an AI-driven software solution targeting the problem of comprehensive dental caries detection. Our software aims to locate any and all caries present in a patient's dental X-ray, including and especially the caries most challenging for humans to find. A core value proposition of our technology is that it is fully agnostic to the dentist's current imaging software and sensor setup, and Dentuit has pursued a unique user interface (UI) realizing this goal. This technology will enable dental imaging vendors to quickly pilot the dental AI user experience (UX) and iterate on their respective computer vision models at scale. With Dentuit's patent-pending interoperable UI/UX invention, Dentifai also facilitates dentists' trialing dental AI using their existing, preferred clinical workflow as-is.

No solution comparable to Dentifai exists (or is on the horizon) for the market of dental AI solutions. Existing caries detection devices and software are too cumbersome to integrate and operate, while current radiographic caries detection technology adjunctively relies on rudimentary algorithms for basic pattern detection. Dentifai is staged to offer dentists economic benefits leapfrogging any existing ecosystem of dental imaging software, seamlessly enhancing dentists with new insights to outperform their current individual caries detection ability. By providing a built-in consensus feedback mechanism that increases confidence, enabling more visually compelling case presentations, Dentuit's Dentifai product will help bring about a new paradigm of value-first dentistry, building patient trust with data-driven reliability, and saving costs all-around by facilitating earlier prevention and minimally invasive treatment.

In this STTR Phase I project we have pushed the envelope on two disruptive innovations: the UMSOD Dental X-ray database (UDXR) and DentalXNet (DXN). UDXR relies on our collaborative annotation protocol to create what is among the highest-quality of medical imaging datasets, and is also the largest known dataset of digital dental X-rays to date. DXN is an advanced machine learning semantic segmentation approach using deep learning (convolutional neural networks, among other techniques) to identify dental caries in digital X-rays, including caries that dentists commonly view as the hardest-to-spot. Our initial human-machine studies have quantitatively and qualitatively demonstrated the ability of our trained DXN model to find and correctly assess caries missed by dentists. The aims of this STTR effort have thus been three-fold: engineering a ground truth assessment of dental caries in digital X-rays, overcoming the many unique computer vision challenges that caries present by developing a novel machine learning approach, and addressing end user pain points with a seamless visualization software that plugs into any dentist's preferred digital X-ray workflow. In training DXN on UDXR and deploying in the Dentifai software, Dentuit's has created an innovative new technology that will serve to objectively standardize a central aspect of every general dentist's workflow, helping usher in the next era of data-driven dental care delivery.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2021
Modified by: Daniel Lee
